titleStmt.title: The Dish Burzgǟn
TUNOCENT Dataset
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 31647

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

media.desc: The informant has not explicitly agreed to the publication of the audio recording. Thus, the audio recording is available only to the research project itself.

monogr.title: Semitic dialects and dialectology : fieldwork - community - change

biblStruct.note: My paper presents the transcription and translation of two texts in the dialect of the northwestern Tunisian town of il-Kǟf (el Kef ). The texts were recorded during fieldwork carried out for the TUNOCENT project. The speaker gives the recipes for traditional dishes and the various kinds of bread typical of the il-Kǟf region. Linguistic notes are given in section 3 to show the local linguistic peculiarities of the dialect. Some final remarks will summarise the differences and similarities in linguistics between the featured texts and other Bedouin-type dialects in Tunisia.Keywords Arabic dialectology, Tunisian dialects, Bedouin dialects, areal linguistics, material culture, field research

spanGrp.span: The famous food of il-Kǟf is called burzgǟn. It is made in… we cook it in the month of May, on the fifteenth of May. We call it “the feast of May”.

At that time we have a lot of green salad. At the same time the people of il-Kǟf, (the people of) all the (other) governorates know that, whenever we say burzgǟn, (we mean) the Kefi burzgǟn. It is eaten in May.
In order to prepare and cook burzgǟn in il-Kǟf, we buy dried fruits,
dry fruits which are almonds, pine nuts, walnuts, hazelnuts and dagla dates. And we buy lamb meat.
Of course, all the Kefan people have couscous at home and everything that is needed to cook it, and milk and butter.[...] And sugar.
In order to prepare the dish burzgǟn we fry the dried fruits, we roast them. We cut the dagla dates into four, boil the milk, and let the butter melt.
We let the sun-dried couscous steam. At the same time we place the meat that, after washing, we have spiced with a pinch of salt and rosemary.
It is green rosemary that (grows) in the mountains and sends forth a nice aroma. We place it (i.e. the meat), let it steam, and we call it knǟf.
After we have let the couscous steam, we open (the couscous chunk) slowly and dissipate it with some butter. We make a layer of couscous.
We garnish (it with) the dried fruits that we have roasted, which are the almonds, the hazelnuts, the pine nuts, and the walnuts;
and at the same time the pieces of dagla dates that we have cleaned and quartered.
We arrange it as decoration in (different) sections: A field like this with almonds, (another with) walnuts, (another with) hazelnuts, (one) with pine nuts, and (one) with dagla dates.
Like this it shapes a rose. We continue with the couscous. We make one more layer of couscous mixed with sugar and butter.
After that we make the last (thing), the decoration of the couscous. We make different sections with those dried fruits that we have roasted and with which we made the first layer.
Different sections of dried fruits and dagla dates. At the same time we have the milk that has become hot, and we have the piece of butter that we put in a pan and that has melted.
At the same time we have the pieces of meat that are called knǟf, that are steaming in the couscous steamer with the smell of rosemary, the smell of which spreads fragrance.
We pour that milk, we pour a layer of butter and then a bit of milk, not too much.
And then we place those pieces of meat that are cooked, they are cooked very well. We put one piece of meat next to the other.
Its beauty lies in its form (which is like) a rose and (in its arrangement) in (various) sections with those dried fruits.
And in those pieces of meat that were cooked with rosemary and called knǟf. That is the dish of il-Kǟf […]
Eat (it) and bon appétit!
Of course there is green salad on the table; there is sour milk; there is an earthen plate, because when we serve the burzgǟn we put it on an earthen plate.
It has the form of a decorated earthen plate. That can be called a Kefan dish, the burzgǟn.
It is eaten in the month of May, beginning with the fifteenth of May. It is a big celebration in the governorate of il-Kǟf.
